zXtKRwB1rw4XMRXcE5Fn.title: Variables and Data Types
zXtKRwB1rw4XMRXcE5Fn.content:
What is a Variable?

A variable is a container for storing data values. In JavaScript, you can declare a variable using var, let, or const. 

// Example:
let name = "Alice";
const age = 25;
var isStudent = true;

Variable Keywords

  • let – block-scoped, can be reassigned.
  • const – block-scoped, cannot be reassigned.
  • var – function-scoped, older and less recommended.

Common Data Types

  • String – text, e.g. "Hello"
  • Number – numeric values, e.g. 42
  • Boolean – true or false
  • Undefined – a variable declared but not assigned
  • Null – intentionally empty value
  • Object – complex data structures (arrays, functions, etc.)

Examples:

let city = "New York";        // String
let year = 2025;              // Number
let isLoggedIn = false;       // Boolean
let score;                    // Undefined
let empty = null;             // Null
let user = { name: "Ellie" }; // Object

Quick Tip

Use typeof to check the type of a variable: 

console.log(typeof city); // "string"
console.log(typeof year); // "number"

tasks.text: Make a String variable called myName
Create a Number variable called age
Create a Boolean variable called isStudent

ikWyuQmAifhepuY3zivt.title: Operators
ikWyuQmAifhepuY3zivt.content:
Operators are used to perform operations on values and variables. JavaScript supports different types of operators.

Arithmetic Operators

Used to perform basic math operations:

  • + Addition
  • - Subtraction
  • * Multiplication
  • / Division
  • % Modulus
  • ** Exponentiation
let x = 10;
let y = 2;
console.log(x + y); // 12
console.log(x % y); // 0

Comparison Operators

Used to compare values and return true or false:

  • == Equal to (loose)
  • === Equal to (strict)
  • != Not equal (loose)
  • !== Not equal (strict)
  • >, <, >=, <= Greater/less than
console.log(5 == "5");  // true
console.log(5 === "5"); // false

Logical Operators

Used for boolean logic:

  • && AND
  • || OR
  • ! NOT
let a = true;
let b = false;
console.log(a && b); // false
console.log(a || b); // true
console.log(!a);     // false

Assignment Operators

Used to assign values to variables:

  • = Assign
  • += Add and assign
  • -= Subtract and assign
  • *=, /= Multiply/divide and assign
let num = 5;
num += 3; // num is now 8

tasks.text: Create a variable called result and set it to 5 + 3
Create a variable called remainder and set it to 10 % 3
Create a variable called isEqual and set it to whether 5 == '5'

D2yjhqRhs4bZ2ZLIZk32.title: Conditional Statements
D2yjhqRhs4bZ2ZLIZk32.content:
Conditional statements are used to perform different actions based on different conditions.

if Statement

The if statement runs a block of code if a condition is true.

let age = 18;

if (age >= 18) {
  console.log("You are an adult.");
}

if...else Statement

The if...else statement runs one block if the condition is true, and another if it is false.

let isRaining = true;

if (isRaining) {
  console.log("Take an umbrella.");
} else {
  console.log("Enjoy the sunshine!");
}

else if Statement

Use else if to test multiple conditions.

let score = 85;

if (score >= 90) {
  console.log("Grade: A");
} else if (score >= 80) {
  console.log("Grade: B");
} else {
  console.log("Keep studying!");
}

switch Statement

The switch statement is used to perform different actions based on different values.

let day = "Monday";

switch (day) {
  case "Monday":
    console.log("Start of the week!");
    break;
  case "Friday":
    console.log("Almost weekend!");
    break;
  default:
    console.log("Just another day.");
}

tasks.text: Create a variable age set to 18, then use an if statement to set output to "You are an adult." if age is 18 or more
Create a variable day set to "Monday" and use a switch statement to set dayMessage to "Start of the week!"

Hxq9RwJHlpievmU3r3R4.title: Loops
Hxq9RwJHlpievmU3r3R4.content:
Loops let you run the same block of code multiple times. JavaScript provides several types of loops.

for Loop

Use a for loop when you know how many times you want to run the code.

for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  console.log("Number: " + i);
}

while Loop

The while loop runs as long as a condition is true.

let count = 0;

while (count < 3) {
  console.log("Count: " + count);
  count++;
}

do...while Loop

The do...while loop runs the code block at least once before checking the condition.

let num = 1;

do {
  console.log("Number is: " + num);
  num++;
} while (num <= 3);

for...of Loop

The for...of loop is useful for iterating over arrays or strings.

let fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"];

for (let fruit of fruits) {
  console.log(fruit);
}

break and continue

break exits the loop early, and continue skips to the next iteration.

for (let i = 1; i <= 5; i++) {
  if (i === 3) continue;
  if (i === 5) break;
  console.log(i);
}
// Output: 1, 2, 4

tasks.text: Use a for loop to add the numbers 1 through 5 and store the result in a variable called sum
Create a while loop that adds numbers 0 to 2 to a string variable called output
Use a do...while loop to build a string result that contains numbers 1 to 3

yjY25mTzuIGbnYLD2C3M.title: Functions
yjY25mTzuIGbnYLD2C3M.content:
Functions are blocks of code designed to perform a particular task. They help you organize and reuse code.

Declaring a Function

Use the function keyword followed by a name, parentheses, and a block of code.

function greet() {
  console.log("Hello!");
}
greet(); // Calls the function

Function Parameters

Functions can take input values called parameters.

function greet(name) {
  console.log("Hello, " + name + "!");
}
greet("Alice"); // Output: Hello, Alice!

Return Values

Functions can return values using the return keyword.

function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}
let result = add(3, 4);
console.log(result); // 7

Function Expressions

You can also assign functions to variables.

const sayHi = function() {
  console.log("Hi there!");
};
sayHi();

Arrow Functions

Arrow functions are a shorter way to write functions.

const multiply = (x, y) => {
  return x * y;
};
console.log(multiply(2, 5)); // 10

Why Use Functions?

  • Reuse code easily
  • Keep your code organized
  • Make your programs easier to read and maintain

tasks.text: Create a function called greet
Make a function called greet that takes a name and sets greeted to 'Hello, ' followed by the name and an exclamation mark
Create a function called add that takes two numbers and returns their sum. Call it with 4 and 5 and store the result in sum

aYs6sAmJmXwjXjab4otR.title: Arrays
aYs6sAmJmXwjXjab4otR.content:
An array is a special variable that can hold multiple values at once.

Creating an Array

let fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"];
console.log(fruits);

Accessing Array Elements

You access array elements by their index (starting at 0).

console.log(fruits[0]); // "apple"
console.log(fruits[2]); // "cherry"

Changing Values

fruits[1] = "blueberry";
console.log(fruits); // ["apple", "blueberry", "cherry"]

Array Length

Use the length property to find the number of items in an array.

console.log(fruits.length); // 3

Common Array Methods

  • push() – Add to the end
  • pop() – Remove from the end
  • shift() – Remove from the beginning
  • unshift() – Add to the beginning
  • indexOf() – Find the index of an item
fruits.push("date");
console.log(fruits); // ["apple", "blueberry", "cherry", "date"]

fruits.pop();
console.log(fruits); // ["apple", "blueberry", "cherry"]

Looping Through Arrays

for (let i = 0; i < fruits.length; i++) {
  console.log(fruits[i]);
}

for (let fruit of fruits) {
  console.log(fruit);
}

Why Use Arrays?

  • Store multiple values in a single variable
  • Easily organize and loop through data
  • Use powerful built-in methods to manipulate data

tasks.text: Create an array called colors with three color names
Create a variable firstColor and set it to the first item in the colors array
Change the second item in the colors array to "green"

hBFHgiZuAlymlPzQq7AS.title: Objects
hBFHgiZuAlymlPzQq7AS.content:
Objects are used to store related data and functionality in key-value pairs.

Creating an Object

let person = {
  name: "Alice",
  age: 25,
  isStudent: true
};

Accessing Properties

console.log(person.name); // "Alice"
console.log(person["age"]); // 25

Modifying Properties

person.age = 26;
person["isStudent"] = false;
console.log(person);

Adding New Properties

person.city = "New York";
console.log(person);

Deleting Properties

delete person.isStudent;
console.log(person);

Objects with Functions (Methods)

let user = {
  name: "Bob",
  greet: function() {
    console.log("Hello, " + this.name);
  }
};
user.greet();

Why Use Objects?

  • Group related data together
  • Model real-world entities (e.g. users, cars, settings)
  • Use methods to add behavior to data

tasks.text: Create an object called person with a property name set to 'Alice'
Add a property age with value 30 to the person object
Remove a property isStudent from the person object

IL9bIq9ByaJr6KVLSyDX.title: Classes
IL9bIq9ByaJr6KVLSyDX.content:
Classes are templates for creating objects. They let you define reusable blueprints for objects with properties and methods.

Defining a Class

class Person {
  constructor(name, age) {
    this.name = name;
    this.age = age;
  }

  greet() {
    console.log("Hi, my name is " + this.name);
  }
}

Creating an Object from a Class

let alice = new Person("Alice", 25);
alice.greet(); // "Hi, my name is Alice"

Adding Methods

class Calculator {
  add(a, b) {
    return a + b;
  }

  subtract(a, b) {
    return a - b;
  }
}

let calc = new Calculator();
console.log(calc.add(3, 2)); // 5

Inheritance

You can create a class that inherits from another using extends.

class Animal {
  speak() {
    console.log("Animal speaks");
  }
}

class Dog extends Animal {
  speak() {
    console.log("Woof!");
  }
}

let pet = new Dog();
pet.speak(); // "Woof!"

Why Use Classes?

  • Organize related code into reusable templates
  • Create multiple objects from one blueprint
  • Use inheritance to share behavior across classes

tasks.text: Create an instance alice of Person with a name property set to 'Alice'

tasks.check: typeof alice.greet === 'function' && alice.greet() == 'Hi, my name is Alice'
tasks.text: Add a method greet to Person that returns 'Hi, my name is ' plus the name
